clean_story:
Decisions under pressure. Leaders rely on sharp thinking.


"Critical thinking" means questioning assumptions, like checking a map before a trip instead of guessing the way.


Good leaders don’t just give orders—they ask, "Why?" before "How?"
Like a firefighter assessing a burning building: they spot risks, weigh options, then act.
A CEO might pause before launching a product, testing it with 100 users first.
A coach studies an opponent’s last five games to predict their next move.
Both avoid costly mistakes by thinking ahead.


The best leaders also admit, "I don’t know"—then seek answers.
Nelson Mandela studied Afrikaans in prison to understand his jailers.
Sherlock Holmes noticed small details others missed.
Critical thinking turns chaos into clarity.


Bias traps.
Group dynamics.
The cost of hesitation.
